title: Article_Title
content: Effect of bandgap alignment on the photoreduction of CO<sub>2</sub> into methane based on Cu<sub>2</sub>O-decorated CuO microspheres

title: Abstract
content: In the paper, two kinds of Cu2O-decorated CuO microspheres composed with nanoflakes were prepared by using two different methods.Their electron behaviors were studied from the XPS spectra and photoelectrochemical measurements.Both samples are p-type CuO covered with an amount of Cu2O nanoparticles on their surface.Combined with their bandgaps and flat band potentials, CuO-Mic has a well-matched bandgap alignment between Cu2O and CuO, which is favorable for the separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs.Those photogenerated carriers are beneficial for the conversion of CO2 to CH4, as an 8-electron process for the conversion of CO2 to CH4 will consume more photogenerated electrons for the chemical reactions than that of the 2-electron process for CO2 reduction to CO.Therefore, CuO-Mic has much better photocatalytic activity for CO2 reduction to CH4 with a CH4 yield ten times higher than that of CuO-Hyd under a visible light irradiation, the CO yields of the CO2 reduction are identical.

title: Experimental
content: CuO microspheres were prepared by two different methods, the standard one-step hydrothermal procedure (CuO-Hyd) and microwave process (CuO-Mic) respectively.All chemicals used in this study had analytical-grade purity.In detail, 1.165 g Cu(NO3)23H2O was dissolved in 40 mL of deionized water under constant magnetic stirring for approximately 10 min.After that, 2 mL of ammonium hydroxide (25 wt ) was added dropwise to the green aqueous solution.On the one hand, the solution was transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, it retained sealed at 90 C for 3 h.When CuO samples were grown in a reaction tank at 90 C for 2.5 h by microwave approach, following above procedure, the obtained black precipitates (CuO-Hyd and CuO-Mic) were separated by centrifugation, washed 3 times with water and ethanol, and dried in air at approximately 60 C for 8 h respectively. The morphologies of the obtained products were checked by a Hitachi S4800 filed-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM).Crystal phases were analyzed by a powder X-ray diffractometer (XRD, MiniFlex 600, Rigaku) with mono-chromatized Cu K radiation.High-A c c e p t e d M a n u s c r i p t resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, Tecnai G2 F30 S-TWIN) was obtained at the accelerating voltage of 300 kV.Raman measurements were conducted at room temperature using a Renishaw in Via Reflex Raman spectrometer with 532 nm lines.A 532 nm laser caused an incident power at the prepared nanomaterials of 3 mW, which used output power of 20 mW and objective lens magnified 50 times.Light absorption measurements were carried out using a UV-vis-NIR spectrophotometer (UV-vis, Cary-5000, Varian) with an integrating sphere.In addition, the chemical states of Sn and O elements were analyzed by Xray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo ESCALAB250Xi) which was equipped with a standard monochromatic Al-K source (h1486.6eV). CO2 reduction.The photocatalyst CuO was firstly placed in the photocatalytic evaluation unit with the volume of the reaction system about 230 ml.Then 0.1g samples were evenly spread in an acetabuliform reactor of glass with an area of 4.2 cm 2 .In the photocatalytic evaluation unit, the xenon lamp of 300 W was used as the light source.Before the high-purity CO2 gas injection into glass, waters should be added to the photocatalytic evaluation device and the device must be kept vacuum.After dark adsorption for 12 hours, the photocatalytic reaction was carried out under light conditions.The gas in the photocatalytic evaluation device was extracted for detection for every hour, until the gas production became balanced which indicated the catalytic process was completed.The measurements were carried out in Jiangsu Key Laboratory for Nano Technology, Nanjing University.The setup can be found in Figure S5 of Ref. 23 XRD measurements of the prepared samples were carried out to describe the structures, as displayed in Figure 1a).The XRD patterns show that the crystalline structures of both samples can well match toCuO(JCPDS No. 48-1548).Raman spectra were carried out to determine the constituents of the preparedsamples, as shown in Figure 1b).It shows that there are three obvious peaks at 287, 338 and 620 cm -1 .The Raman spectra of pure CuO nanorods with three peaks at 297, 346 and 633 cm -1 were regarded as the Ag, B1g, and B2g characteristic modes of CuO with monoclinic crystal symmetry 24,25 .As reported by Chen et al., Raman phonon modes will red-shift with increasing surface areas. 26The temperature also led to the mode's redshift. 27In Ref. 28, Raman mode with about 30cm -1 red-shift was observed.

title: Conclusions
content: The Cu2O-decorated CuO Microspheres were prepared and used to reduce CO2 to CO or to CH4.As discussed above, the existence of Cu2O is very important for the reduction of CO2 to CO or to CH4, since the photogenerated electrons have more negative potential than the reduction potential of CO2 to CO or to CH4, which guarantees the occurrence of the reduction of CO2.Because of the type-II heterostructure Cu2O/CuO, the photogenerated electron-hole pairs can be effectively separated under a visible light.Sample CuO-Mic has a good energy band alignment and higher donor carrier density, it has much better photocatalytic activity for CO2 reduction to CH4.The results will be helpful for understanding the reduction process of Figure 1: (a) XRD patterns of samples CuO-Hyd and CuO-Mic; (b) Ramanspectrum with excitation at 532 nm; SEM images of (c) CuO-Hyd and (d) CuO-Mic. Figure 1c) and 1d) is the SEM images of CuO-Hyd and CuO-Mic, respectively.The Figure shows that both samples are composed with microspheres, where microspheres are self-assembled with nanoflakes.While the nanoflakes in CuO-Hyd are more thicker and denser than that in CuO-Mic, meaning that sample CuO-Mic may have a larger specific surface area than CuO-Hyd.
